file_content.text: My lord, you are just in time. The acolytes should be returning shortly.
Unfortunately, my three-eyed one is out, but your acolyte is still in the running.
The Twi'lek has undeniable aptitude, but he's wildly out of control. Too much of an animal, but then, what do you expect?
There's something vaguely unsettling about bone-face. He's hardly said a word. But he's got a determined glint in his eye. Reminds me of you.
Overseer. I've returned with the carving, as you requested.
Ah, there you are. My lord, it looks as if you were right.
Ah, there you are. My lord, it looks as if we were both wrong.
May I present to you your apprentice.
Ahem.
Maybe I wasn't so wrong after all.
Not so fast, Harkun.
I may not have been as right as you thought.
Not so fast, Harkun.
Ah, bone-face. So you're not dead, then.
I was hoping this wouldn't be over so quickly.
You're alive!
No, it definitely got a lot more interesting. Where is your carving, bone-face?
I'm not going to have to wait for another trial, am I?
You failed, Harkun.
There was only one carving. I'm interested in what bone-face here hopes to prove.
Xalek.
Hmm?
My name is Xalek.
Your carving, my lord.
Slave scum. Did you not listen to the rules of this Academy? You do not murder another acolyte! And in the presence of witnesses!
I'm sorry, my lord. It seems I've failed to teach this miserable dog a single lesson. I will let you know when a new shipment of slaves arrives.
It's alright, Harkun. I like his style.
I want this one.
What's wrong with this one?
Why can't I have Xalek?
I need an apprentice now. I can't wait.
I don't have time for that.
He murdered an acolyte in the Academy walls, in the presence of an overseer and a Lord of the Sith.
To top it off, he's a slave. Sith tradition demands he be executed.
Sith tradition is as old and crumbling as those tombs outside. It needs renovation.
I don't care.
Don't protest.
I'm only telling the truth. I've put up with a lot around here. Training low slaves into Sith Lords.
But if the rules of subterfuge and skill give way to blind murder, then the whole Empire is doomed.
You pick the strangest times to get principles, Harkun.
Apprentice, come with me.
Thanaton will hear of this. I promise you.
Xalek completed his trials fairly. Give him your lightsaber.
[Force Persuade] What murder?
Xalek completed his trials fairly. I will give him my lightsaber.
Congratulations, Xalek. Improbably, you have earned the right to become Sith. Take my lightsaber.
Doomed or not, you won't live to see it happen.
Don't worry. [Kill Harkun]
Ugh.
Do not make me remind you the cost of disobedience.
I am the Sith Lord here.
No, my lord. But Thanaton will hear of this.
My lord.
I hope you're ready to fight.
We have a lot of work to do.
Always.
I have places to be. You fall behind, I won't look back for you.
Let's go.
My eyes are on you, lord.
I think you'll fit in well with my crew.
I like you.
Hmm.
My lord. Your slaves are about to finish their final trial. You might want to be present for this.
Don't start the fun without me.
I'll be right there.
I will try to wait until you arrive.
In case you hadn't noticed, my hands are a bit full with this Thanaton business.
I don't really have time.
Naturally. I will wait.
Thank you for telling me.
I appreciate it.
You're welcome. This should be very interesting.
Time for death, Twi'lek.
It would be my pleasure to kill you.
Quiet, both of you. You know your trial. Now go.
Hmm.
My lord. You just missed the latest trial. As you can see, we have a wild group. All except the human. He was surprisingly quick to die.
Through no interference of yours, I trust?
As long as it was fair.
These wretches can get themselves killed without my help.
The trials are meant to separate the weak from the strong.
Good.
You have come a long way, my lord.
I think I liked him best.
That's a shame.
He certainly had promise.
My credits are on the three-eyed one, personally.
Uglier than my twisted Sith grandmother, but he has the same determined glint you had.
Uglier than my twisted Sith grandmother, but he has a vicious streak uncommon in slaves.
I wouldn't bet against him.
It's a safe wager.
You know, I'm starting to enjoy working with these misshapen freaks. At least it's never boring.
I would've preferred to see the human prevail, but you can only ask so much.
I'll take that bet. My credits are on the Kaleesh.
I prefer the bone-face.
I'll take that bet. My credits are on the one who crushed skulls in the Hutt's palace.
I prefer the Twi'lek.
I didn't know you were the gambling type, my lord.
While you're here, is there anything particular you want to accomplish with these trials? Many Sith Lords use the acolytes to gather things from the tombs for them.
Anything that will help me in my struggle with Thanaton would be appreciated.
I can use more artifacts.
I think I know something.
Whatever you send them for, make sure it's a challenge. I don't want a weak apprentice.
Just make it hard.
When have I ever tolerated weakness?
I leave their trials to your judgment, Harkun.
It's up to you.
I'll contact you when they are on their last trial, so that you can arrive in time for the results.
Hi there.
